issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: Exceptions like InvalidResourceBlacklistRequestException, InvalidResourceRequestException, InvalidApplicationMasterRequestException etc are currently inside ResourceManager and not visible to clients.
fields.summary: Create exceptions package in common/api for yarn and move client facing exceptions to them

comments.body:
Attaching patch.

Thanks,
Mayank

Does it really make sense to put exceptions in their own package? Is their any precedent for this in other well known Java libraries? It seems to me that we should just put these in the package that is likely to throw them, i.e. org.apache.hadoop.yarn.client.api. A couple documentation nits: {code} - * requested memory/vcore is non-negative and not greater than max + * requested memory/vcore is non-negative and not greater than max throws + * exception InvalidResourceRequestException when there is + * invalid request {code} "throws" should be on a separate line as "@throws" {code} + /* + * This method will throw InvalidResourceBlacklistRequestException + * If the resource is not be able to add to black list. + */ {code} "If the resource is not be able to add to black list." should be "if the resource is not able to be added to the blacklist."

{color:green}+1 overall{color}.  Here are the results of testing the latest attachment 
  http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12591910/YARN-912-trunk-1.patch
  against trunk revision .

    {color:green}+1 @author{color}.  The patch does not contain any @author tags.

    {color:green}+1 tests included{color}.  The patch appears to include 1 new or modified test files.

    {color:green}+1 javac{color}.  The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

    {color:green}+1 javadoc{color}.  The javadoc tool did not generate any warning messages.

    {color:green}+1 eclipse:eclipse{color}.  The patch built with eclipse:eclipse.

    {color:green}+1 findbugs{color}.  The patch does not introduce any new Findbugs (version 1.3.9) warnings.

    {color:green}+1 release audit{color}.  The applied patch does not increase the total number of release audit warnings.

    {color:green}+1 core tests{color}.  The patch passed unit tests in hadoop-yarn-project/hadoop-yarn/hadoop-yarn-api hadoop-yarn-project/hadoop-yarn/hadoop-yarn-server/hadoop-yarn-server-resourcemanager.

    {color:green}+1 contrib tests{color}.  The patch passed contrib unit tests.

Test results: https://builds.apache.org/job/PreCommit-YARN-Build/1463//testReport/

This message is automatically generated.

Thanks [~sandyr] for review

Updated the review comments.

Thanks,
Mayank

This message is automatically generated.
+1 to the doc changes.  I still think we should move the exceptions out of their own package and into client.api.  Any thoughts on that?

What does this mean? Non javadoc but still has @see ?
{code}
+  /*
+   * (non-Javadoc)
+   * 
+   * @see
+   * org.apache.hadoop.yarn.api.ApplicationMasterProtocol#registerApplicationMaster
+   * (
+   * org.apache.hadoop.yarn.api.protocolrecords.RegisterApplicationMasterRequest
+   * )
{code}

Sandy, what do you mean by client.api? Which client?

bq. Sandy, what do you mean by client.api? Which client?
My bad.  I thought these were only relevant for AMRMClient.  But my main point was that there's not much precedent and it's not very useful to package classes by what kind of class they are.  I would say we should put them into org.apache.hadoop.yarn.

I'm now noticing that YarnException and YarnRuntimeException are in the org.apache.hadoop.yarn.exceptions package as well, so if it's too late to change that, I'm fine with putting these in the exceptions package as well.

Yeah, it's too late to change YarnException etc. I am fine putting all these in yarn-api/o.a.h.y.exceptions.

We should also document these in the java protocols. For e.g., InvalidApplicationMasterRequestException should be put in javadoc for ApplicationMasterProtocol.registerApplicationMaster().

Thanks [~bikassaha][~vinodkv]and [~sandyr]for the review.

Updated the patch with comments.

Thanks,
Mayank

This message is automatically generated.

Mostly looks good. Can you please do the following too?
 - Add InvalidResourceBlacklistRequestException to javadoc of ApplicationMasterProtocol.allocate()
 - Also, for ApplicationMasterProtocol.allocate() document when/in what case such specific exception will be thrown.
 - Similarly, add InvalidResourceRequestException to javadoc of ApplicationMasterProtocol.allocate() and ApplicationClientProtocol.submitApplication(). And then specifiy what it means and when it can be thrown.

Once you do that, all the non-javadoc stuff can be thrown out completely from the patch.
Can you also take care of NMNotYetReadyException and InvalidContainerException too?

Thanks [~vinodkv]for the review.

Updating the patch with all the comments.

Thanks,
Mayank
